video.title_en: How an Eclipse Proved Einstein Right

summary.text_en: British astronomer Arthur Eddington used the total solar eclipse of May 29, 1919, to conduct a crucial test of Einstein's 'General Relativity'. According to Einstein, the Sun's mass should curve 'spacetime', causing starlight passing nearby to bend. Eddington led an expedition to Principe Island in West Africa to photograph star positions during the eclipse. Comparing these to reference photos taken at night, he found the starlight was deflected by ~1.75 arcseconds, matching Einstein's prediction and disproving Newton's (0.87 arcseconds).
key_points_en: Made Einstein a global celebrity overnight

story.text_en: This is a story of science transcending war. During WWI, Eddington (a British pacifist) fought to test the theory of a German scientist (Einstein). On the day of the eclipse in Principe, it rained heavily, and Eddington was near despair. Miraculously, the clouds parted just before totality. He frantically photographed the Hyades star cluster. Months later in London, when the results supporting Einstein were announced at the Royal Society, the room erupted. J.J. Thomson called it 'one of the greatest achievements in the history of human thought.'

fun_facts.text_en: When asked what he would have done if the experiment proved him wrong, Einstein famously replied: 'Then I would have felt sorry for the dear Lord. The theory is correct anyway.'
The London Times headline the next day read: 'Revolution in Science: New Theory of the Universe; Newtonian Ideas Overthrown.' It is arguably the most famous science headline in history.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine a trampoline (spacetime) with a bowling ball (Sun) in the middle causing a dip. If you roll a marble (light) past the bowling ball, it curves.
Newton thought light went straight (or bent very little). Einstein thought light followed the 'dip' in the trampoline.
During an eclipse (which blocked the Sun's glare), Eddington took photos of stars behind the Sun. He found the stars had 'shifted' position, and the shift matched Einstein's 'dip' perfectly. He proved gravity isn't just a force, it's the bending of space.

applications.text_en: The theory Eddington verified isn't just academic. GPS satellites *must* adjust their clocks daily for General Relativity effects (time slows in gravity), or your map location would be off by kilometers every day.

applications.text_en: This 'light bending' is now a primary tool (Gravitational Lensing) for astronomers to detect dark matter and see distant galaxies by using galaxy clusters as giant magnifying glasses.

impact.text_en: This observation was a pivot point in history. It marked the end of the 200-year 'Newtonian Era' and the beginning of the 'Einsteinian Era'. It didn't just change our fundamental understanding of the universe (spacetime); it transformed a reclusive theoretical physicist (Einstein) into a global cultural icon.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Einstein (whose General Relativity was the theory Eddington sought to verify)
Isaac Newton (whose classical mechanics predicted a smaller deflection, serving as the 'null hypothesis')

influenced.contribution_en: Edwin Hubble (once GR was verified, Hubble's observations led to Big Bang cosmology based on Einstein's equations)
Oppenheimer (the confirmation of light bending made the concept of black holesâ€”where light cannot escapeâ€”physically plausible)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Eddington caught the bending of starlight in the darkness, announcing to the world that space itself is curved.

quiz.question_en: What data did Eddington measure during the 1919 eclipse to verify Einstein's theory?
options_en: The change in the Sun's brightness
The 'shift in position' of stars near the Sun
quiz.explanation_en: Einstein predicted the Sun's gravity would 'bend' light passing near it. This would cause stars seen near the Sun to appear slightly 'shifted' outwards from their true positions. Eddington measured this tiny shift.
